title: sokani
author: sokani
content: https://mempool.space/block/00000000000000000000b7070e88525e4064ab36df7cfbe34d785bbc6eb491eaOn friday, luck smiled on a solo miner who solved block 888737 that contains 2327 transactions using DIY FutureBit Apollo machine. The solo miner went home with the 3.125 BTC block reward and an extra 0.032 BTC from transaction fees. This is a major win for the solo miner considering that Bitcoin mining difficulty has gone as high as 112.15T, making it very difficult to compete with large mining pools with immense computational power.

comments.author: Dunamisx
comments.body: In anything we do, there's always a time for us to bear the cost of it and also another time where we can enjoy from the efforts we have rendered in the past, that is how a balanced life should be, not that we won't be challenged at all, but when ever we had one, we should also have another to counter the first we had and make things happier on us, miners have their own challenging times too, just as we also know of how they mostly enjoy increasing mining fee rate during the period the mempool was congested and transaction fee becomes higher, this serves as his own seasons and opportunity to smile being a miner.

comments.author: mindrust
comments.body: Does it have to make it to the headlines every time a guy wins the lottery? Some lucky solo miner won $266k, cool but people win such prizes every day. I hope no sensible person tries solo mining after reading these news with the hopes of winning the block reward, it won’t happen. Do the pool mining thing instead, it will create a consistent cash income.

comments.author: takuma sato
comments.body: Does anyone have a list of solo-mining records? it would be interesting to see who has made the highest amounts of mined blocks with an one-man operation. Electricity costs aside, all things equal we could see what of these machines are the best performers. I remember reading something about one called BitAxe that was apparently kicking ass in this small-miner department. I was even considering buying some to try my luck if after doing the numbers I decided that it makes sense to do so, but no before I get some numbers to compare how it works vs other counterparts that could be compared to.At the end of the day if you care about Bitcoin you should be mining it even if you mine it at a loss, this helps the network and ultimately helps your holdings, so it would be like paying a subscription fee to something sort of thing. Like paying someone to store your gold in a vault, but your miners are the vault.

comments.body: Quoteif you're interested in and want to try, there is a guide.NERDMINER: Bitcoin lottery minersThe original Nerdminers are beyond useless toys because they are mining using only a very small CPU. With a speed of just 55Kh/sec - that's right, 55 thousand hashes per-sec - and a Work Diff of 1 you will be lucky to even process a single share in the avg time of 10min between blocks.Later - and much more expensive - Nerds that have ASIC's in them at least have a decent speed over 1Th/s which will give one a much better shot at finding a block. Still terrible odds against you but at least is a viable miner.

comments.body: I am truly happy for that miner and I hope they will put that money to good use. But I also agree with mindtrust that it's kind of like winning a lottery, right? comments.body: It should be pointed out that the solo's ^^ pointed at -ck's solo pool covered a wide range of hash rates. Last year one of Sidehack's Compac-F USB sticks (around 350THs) found a block but most of the 'winners' were pointing a ton of rental hash at it, often as much as 500 or more PH. I believe there are also at least 2 BitAxe's in the mix that were running between 400GHs-4THs. All blocks can be searched for on -ck's pool thread here. Most recent block there was on Mar. 10 by a BitAxe (bitaxeultra4) running 486GHs.Those using rental hash of course did not clear anywhere near as much profit as that lil' Compac-F or BitAxe's did...
